title-group.article-title: Effects of incorporating germinated brown rice on the antioxidant properties of wheat flour chapatti

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Food Science and Technology, Guru Nanak Dev University, Amritsar, India
2School of Public Health, Curtin Health Innovation Research Institute, Curtin University, Perth Western Australia, Australia

author-notes.corresp: H. Singh Gujral, Department of Food Science and Technology, Guru Nanak Dev University, Amritsar, India Email: hsgujral7@yahoo.co.in

abstract.p: Brown rice after germinating for 24 and 48 h was milled into flour and incorporated in whole wheat flour at a level of 10% to prepare chapattis. The objective was to use chapatti as a delivery vehicle for germinated brown rice. The flour blends and chapattis made from the flour blends were evaluated for their antioxidant properties. Incorporating germinated brown rice flour increased the total phenolic content of the flour blend from 1897 to 2144 µg FAE/g. The total flavonoids content increased significantly from 632.3 to1770.9 µg CAE/g and metal chelating activity significantly increased by 71.62%. Antioxidant activity increased significantly by the addition of brown rice flour and addition of 24- and 48-h germinated brown rice flour further increased the antioxidant activity significantly. The total phenolic content and total flavonoids content decrease significantly in all the blends after baking the flour into chapatti. A decrease of 3% to 29% was observed in the total phenolic content and a decrease of 25% to 42% was observed in the total flavonoids content. However, baking of the flour blends into chapatti increased the reducing power, metal chelating activity by three folds and antioxidant activity from 64% to 104%.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Rice (Oryzae sativa) is world’s largest cultivated cereal crop and its consumption provides more than 50% of the daily calories ingested by more than half of the world population. It is consumed in the milled form, that is white rice after the removal of husk and bran. Rice without removal of bran is called brown rice; it has a higher nutritional value but is not preferred by consumers due to its harder and fibrous texture (Gujral et al., 2011a, in press). Bran is a good source of fiber, phytochemicals, minerals and vitamins. Germination of brown rice has been reported to enhance its nutraceutical value with increased level of gamma amino butyric acid (GABA), lysine, vitamin E and dietary fiber, niacin, magnesium, vitamins B1 and B6, respectively. Germinated brown rice (GBR) proves to be suitable for type 2 diabetic patients, because of the high content in dietary fiber, as fiber can regulate blood sugar levels and prevent type 2 diabetes (Kayahara and Kikuichi, 2000).

Wheat is a major cereal in India and is consumed mainly in the form of unleavened flat bread known as chapatti (Gujral and Pathak, 2002). Chapatti is usually prepared from whole wheat flour and the desired quality parameters in chapatti are greater pliability, soft texture, light creamish brown color, slight chewiness and baked wheat aroma (Gujral et al., 2008). GBR could be incorporated into wheat flour to make chapattis, thus promoting consumption of GBR and also increasing the nutritional value of chapattis. Recent research studies have demonstrated that the phytochemicals like polyphenols and phenolics in whole grains are concentrated in outermost layers and, hence, their removal would lead to products that are less beneficial to health (Shahidi, 2009; Madhujith et al., 2006). It is claimed that grains contain more antioxidants than previously thought due to a relatively high amount of bound components (Pérez-Jiménez and Saura Calixto, 2005). Cereals are therefore potentially good sources of natural antioxidants. Evidences indicate that phenolic compounds have potent antioxidant properties and free radical scavenging capabilities (Shahidi et al., 1992; Yu et al., 2002a). In rice, ferulic acid and p-caumaric acid are the major phenolic compounds and exist in the free, soluble or insoluble bound form which is found in dietary fiber (Sosulski et al., 1982). The natural antioxidants in cereals may function as reducing agents, free radical scavengers, single oxygen quencher and potential complexes of pro-oxidants (Zielinski and Kozlowska, 2000). The objective of the present investigation was to utilize GBR flour in chapatti making and to study the effect of incorporating GBR flour on the antioxidant properties of chapatti and changes in the antioxidant properties upon baking.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Wheat and rice cultivar PBW-343 and PR-111, respectively, were procured from Punjab Agricultural University, Ludhiana (Punjab). The wheat was milled in to whole wheat flour by passing through a stone mill and sieved through 60 BSS sieve to obtain flour of 98% extraction rate.

sec.title: Preparation of GBR
sec.p: The paddy was dehusked in a McGill rice Sheller (Rapsco, Brookshire TX, USA) and brown rice was obtained. The brown rice was steeped for 24 h and care was taken that water was changed at 2-h intervals. The GBR was allowed to germinate (temp. 25 °C, humidity-100%) in a seed germinator (Narang Scientific, New Delhi) for 24 and 48 h (Gujral et al, 2011a). The GBR was dried in a cabinet dryer at 50 °C to a moisture content of 12%. The dried GBR was ground in Super Mill 1500 (Newport Scientific, Australia).

sec.title: Preparation of chapatti
sec.p: Preliminary trials were carried out to determine the amount of water to be added to the flour to develop non-sticky viscoelastic dough that could be easily rolled and sheeted to make a chapatti. Trials were carried out to optimize the level of GBR flour to be added to prepare acceptable chapatti and GBR at a level of 10% was selected. The flour was mixed with optimum water for 3 min in a laboratory mixer (National Manufacturing Company, Lincoln, USA). Dough ball (50 g) was rounded and then placed on a rolling board with guide rails 2 mm in thickness and sheeted. The dough was rolled in one direction, inverted and then rolled in a perpendicular direction. The diameter of the chapattis before and after baking was noted to measure shrinkage (%). The raw chapatti was immediately placed on an electric hot plate at 350 °C and baked for a total of 1 min on both sides. The puffing height of chapatti during baking was noted. The chapatti was allowed to cool for 10 min at 25 °C (80% relative humidity) and then was weighed to determine bake loss. The chapattis were freeze dried (Sim International, USA) and packed in polyethylene pouches and placed in an air tight container at 25 °C. Further freeze dried chapattis were ground in Super Mill 1500 (Newport Scientific, Australia) and passed through 60 BSS sieve and flour stored in airtight container at −20 °C till further analysis.

sec.title: Total phenolic content
sec.p: The total phenolic content (TPC) was determined by the Folin-Ciocalteu specterophotometric method (Sharma and Gujral, 2010b). The sample (200 mg) was extracted with 4 mL acidified methanol (HCl/ methanol/water, 1:80:10, v/v/v) at room temperature (25 °C) for 2 h using wrist action shaker (Narang Scientific, Delhi, India). The mixture was centrifuged at 3000 g for 10 min on a centrifuge (Eltek, RC 4100 F, Mumbai, India). Aliquot of extract (200 µL) was added to 1.5 mL freshly diluted (10 fold) Folin-Ciocalteu reagent. The mixture was allowed to equilibrate for 5 min and then mixed with 1.5 mL of sodium carbonate solution (60 g/L). After incubation at room temperature (25 °C) for 90 min, the absorbance of the mixture was read at 725 nm (Shimadzu, UV-2450, Kyoto, Japan). Acidified methanol was used as a blank. The results were expressed as µg of ferulic acid equivalents per gram of flour.

sec.title: Antioxidant activity
sec.p: Antioxidant activity (AOA) was measured using a modified version of the method explained by Brand-Williams et al. (1995) using free radical 2,2-diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl (DPPH) solution in methanol. Ground barley samples (100 mg) were extracted with 1 mL methanol for 2 h and centrifuged at 3000 g for 10 min. The supernatant (100 µL) was reacted with 3.9 mL of a 6 × 10−5 mol/L of DPPH solution. Absorbance (A) at 515 nm was read at 0 and 30 min using a methanol blank. AOA was calculated as % discoloration.

sec.title: Reducing power
sec.p: The reducing power was measured as described by Zhao et al. (2008). Flour blends (0.5 g) was extracted with 80% methanol on wrist action shaker for 2 h. The supernatant was collected after centrifugation at 10000 g for 10 min. The supernatant (1 mL) was mixed with phosphate buffer (0.2 mol/L, pH 6.6) and 2.5 mL potassium ferricyanide (1%) was added. The mixture was allowed to stand for 20 min at 50 °C. After incubation, 2.5 mL of trichloroacetic acid solution was added to mixture, which was then centrifuged at 10000 g for 10 min. The upper layer of solution was mixed with 2.5 mL deionized water and 0.5 mL ferric chloride (0.1%). The absorbance of the mixture was measured at 700 nm. Increased absorbance of the mixture indicated increased reducing power. A standard curve was prepared using various concentration of ascorbic acid equivalents/g of flour.

sec.title: Metal chelating (Fe+2) activity
sec.p: The metal chelating activity of extract was measured as reported by Dinis et al. (1994). The extract was mixed with 50 µL of ferrous chloride (2 mM/L) and 1.6 mL 80% methanol was added. After 5 min, the reaction was initiated by the addition of ferrozine (100 µL) and the mixture was shaken on vortex. Further, the mixture was incubated at room temperature (25 °C) for 10 min. Absorbance of solution was measured at 562 nm on a spectrophotometer. The chelating activity of the extract for Fe+2 was calculated as follow:

sec.title: Total flavonoids content
sec.p: The total flavonoids content (TFC) was determined as previously described by Jia et al. (1998). The extract (250 µL) was diluted with 1.25 mL distilled water. Then, 5% solution of sodium nitrite was added (75 µL) and the mixture was allowed to stand for 6 min. Further, 150 µL of a 10% aluminium chloride was added and the mixture was allowed to stand for 5 min. After that, 0.5 mL of 1 M sodium hydroxide was added and solution was mixed well. The absorbance was measured immediately at 510 nm using a spectrophotometer. Catechin was used as standard and results were reported.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Analysis of variance (ANOVA) was carried out using Microsoft Excel Software and Fishers least significant difference (LSD) test was used to describe means with 95% confidence. The Pearson correlation coefficients were calculated by SPSS statistical software (SPSS Inc., Chicago, Illinois, USA) at a probability level of p < 0.05.

sec.title: Chapatti dough water absorption, shrinkage, puffing height and bake loss
sec.p:
The dough water absorption and baking characteristics of the control wheat flour and wheat flour containing 10% of GBR flour germinated for 0, 24 and 48 h are shown in Table 1. When brown rice flour was added to the wheat flour, the water absorption of the dough was lowered by 19.0%. A minor and insignificant decrease in water absorption was observed when GBR flour (24 and 48 h) was incorporated. The control chapatti shrank by 4.6% upon baking, which is attributed to denaturation of gluten protein. The addition of ungerminated brown rice (UBR) lowered the chapatti shrinkage by 30.88%. The reduction in shrinkage is attributed to the dilution of gluten protein. The shrinkage was least (2.04%) when GBR (48 h) was added, which can be attributed to presence of proteolytic enzymes in GBR, which breakdown the gluten protein in the wheat flour and hence there was lesser shrinkage (Singh et al., 1998). Table 1.
Effect of addition of brown rice flour on quality parameters of chapatti
Blends/Samples Water absorption (%) Shrinkage (%) Puffing height (cm) Bake loss (%)
Control (wheat flour) 74.3 ± 1.0 b 4.76 ± 0.1 d 2.00 ± 0.5 a 21.65 ± 0.9 d
UBR 60.0 ± 0.2 a 3.29 ± 0.1 b 2.75 ± 0.3 b 13.60 ± 0.6 a
GBR (24 h) 59.6 ± 0.6 a 4.16 ± 0.2 c 3.25 d ± 0.8 d 16.98 ± 0.1 b
GBR (48 h) 59.3 ± 0.4 a 2.04 ± 0.6 a 3.00 c ± 0.5 c 18.06 ± 0.8 c
Standard error 1.83 0.30 0.14 0.83
Note: Values are mean of three replicates ± SD. Means followed by different letters are significant different (p < 0.05). UBR and GBR are ungerminated brown rice and germinated brown rice, respectively.

Puffing height of the chapatti increased by 38% upon addition of UBR. This may be attributed to dilution of gluten protein, as the protein network was weakened and the steam generated during baking process led to greater puffing. Further increase of 18.2% was observed when GBR (24 h) was added. This may be due to the modification of wheat gluten by proteolytic enzymes of germinated rice. This also correlated with shrinkage at this level, however when GBR (48 h) was added the puffing height was lowered to 3 cm. This reduction is attributed to excessive breakdown of gluten protein by proteolytic enzymes from the 48 h GBR.

When UBR was added, the bake loss was lowered by 37.18%. This can be attributed to the increased fiber content contributed by the UBR. Fiber/hydrocolloids have been reported to increase the water absorption capacity, thus lowering the bake loss (Holtekjolen et al., 2008; Sharma and Gujral, 2010a). However, when GBR 24 and 48 h was added, the bake loss increased, which can be attributed to the breakdown of fiber in rice bran due to the carbohydrases produced during the germination process, lowering their molecular weight and water-holding capacity (Tian et al., 2004).

sec.title: Total phenolic content
sec.p:
The TPC of the wheat flour was 2003 µg FAE/g (Table 2). When brown rice flour was added to the wheat flour, the TPC was significantly decreased by 5.3%, whereas addition of 24 h GBR flour increased TPC by 7.0%. When 48 h GBR flour was added to wheat flour, the TPC content showed a significant decrease of 19.4%. After germination, various changes in the phenolic compounds occur which are not only dependent on the type of seeds but also on the process conditions, the presence or absence of light and germination time (Lopez-Amoros et al., 2006). Further, they also reported decrease in trans-ferulic acid and trans p-caumaric acid as germination time increased. Increase in TPC after addition of 24 h GBR could be attributed to the increase in the free phenolic forms due to dismantling of the cell wall during germination (Shibuya, 1984; Gujral et al., 2011b). Tian et al. (2004) reported that during germination of rice, the carbohydrase enzymes hydrolysed the starch to release the bound phenolic compounds increasing the TPC. However, addition of germinated (48 h) brown rice leads to decrease in TPC. This may be attributed to the formation of insoluble complexes with proteins that hinder their extraction (Beta et al., 1999). Sharma and Gujral (2010b) reported that the germination of barley leads to decrease in TPC. Furthermore, alteration of the structure of phenolic compounds upon germination may also be a reason for decrease in TPC. Satwadhar et al. (1981) reported that the decrease in the phenolic content is due to change in their chemical composition and structure. Table 2.
Total phenolic content and antioxidant activity of different blends before and after baking in to chapatti
Total phenolic content (µg FAE/g) Antioxidant activity (%)
Blends/Samples Flour Chapatti Flour Chapatti
Control (wheat flour) 2003 ± 18.0 c, q 1382 ± 25.4 a, p 7.18 ± 0.1 a, p 3.16 ± 0.1 a, q
UBR 1897 ± 2.1 b, q 1356 ± 70.4 a, p 16.60 ± 0.3 c, p 29.0 ± 2.4 c, q
GBR (24 h) 2143 ± 7.1 d, q 2071 ± 85.5 b, q 15.30 ± 0.8 b, p 25.0 ± 3.6 b, q
GBR (48 h) 1612 ± 18.1 a, q 1289 ± 90.2 a, p 15.60 ± 0.1 b, p 31.75 ± 0.6 d, q
Standard error 56.25 91.61 1.09 3.25
Note: Values are mean of three replicates, ± SD. Means followed by a–d are significantly (p < 0.05) different within different blends and by p–q show significant difference of baking within a blend. UBR and GBR are ungerminated brown rice and germinated brown rice, respectively.

After baking, the TPC in control chapatti was reduced to 1382 µg FAE/g. This reduction in TPC after baking can be attributed to the heat effects on flour components. The TPC was significantly lowered when all the above flour blends were baked into chapatti. The highest decrease (28%) was observed in the flour blend containing brown rice flour, whereas the flour containing 48 h GBR flour showed a decrease of 20% and the flour containing 24 h GBR flour showed a decrease of only 3.39% and had the highest TPC (2071 µg FAE/g). Bryngelsson et al. (2002) noticed a significant decrease in caffeic acid, ferulic acid, p-coumaric acid and vanillin after thermal processing of oats and they also reported that thermal processing leads to decrease in phenolic compounds. The decrease in TPC could be due to oxidation of phenolic compounds and degradation of thermal susceptible phenolic compounds (Bryngelsson et al., 2002; Randhir et al., 2008).

sec.title: Antioxidant activity
sec.p: The antioxidant activity (AOA) of the wheat flour was 7.18% (Table 2). A significant increase in AOA was observed when flour from 24 and 48 h GBR was added. This increase may be due to the synthesis of compounds like vitamin C and tocopherols which are responsible for AOA (Sharma and Gujral, 2010b). During germination, the hydrolytic enzymes modify the endosperm and may liberate some of the bound components that play a role in AOA (Doblado et al., 2007).

It was observed that the AOA in flour with UBR was higher than that with GBR (24 and 48 h). The AOA is related to the TPC, however there is no correlation upon germination because many factors are involved. Increase in the free phenolic forms is due to dismantling of the cell wall during germination (Shibuya, 1984; Gujral et al., 2011a, in press). Satwadhar et al. (1981) reported that the decrease in the phenolic content is due to change in their chemical composition and structure. Leaching of phenolic compounds in the soaking water and or due to the degradation of phenolic compounds as a result of enzymatic action has been reported (Sharma and Gujral 2010b; Beta et al. 1999). López-Amorós et al. (2006) reported a decrease in AOA as germination time increased. It was also observed that the TPC in blend with UBR was lower than that in blends with GBR, while the AOA in blend with UBR was higher than that in blends with GBR. This may be attributed to the absence of correlation between TPC and AOA upon germination (Sharma and Gujral, 2010b) and due to reasons discussed above. Frias et al. (2005) studied the antioxidant activity and vitamins C and E contents of raw and germinated seeds of Lupinus and observed that the germination increased the content of alpha tocopherol.

The AOA was significantly increased when all the above flour blends were baked into chapatti. The highest increase (103.5%) was observed in the flour blend containing GBR flour (48 h) whereas the flour containing 24 h GBR flour showed an increase of 38.8% and the flour containing UBR flour showed an increase of 74.7%. Dewanto et al. (2002) found an increase in AOA after thermal treatment of sweet corn. Rocha-Guzman et al. (2007) reported similar results in DPPH activity in cooked common beans (Bayo victoria) than in uncooked beans. Many authors claim that higher antioxidant properties of thermally processed foods is attributed to the formation of Maillard products such as HMF (5-hydroxymethyl-2-furaldehyde), which render high AOA (Duenas et al., 2006; Siddhuraju, 2006). Compared with the flour, the AOA in control decreased after baking, while the AOA in blends with UBR and GBR increased after baking. This increase may be attributed to the formation of Maillard browning products after baking of chapatti which increases the AOA. The higher level of free sugars and amino acids after germination (Kayahara and Kikuichi, 2000) and proteins of the rice bran lead to increased Maillard browning that may contribute to the increased AOA.

Nicoli et al. (1997) showed that medium dark roasted coffee brews had the highest AOA due to the formation of Maillard reaction product. An increase in the number of hydroxyl groups in the phenyl ring increases the radical scavenging activity, due to the fact that more hydrogen atoms of the phenolic hydroxyl groups can be donated to stabilize the free radicals (Rice-Evans et al., 1996).

sec.title: Total flavonoids content
sec.p:
The TFC of the wheat flour was 632 µg CE/g (Figure 1). When brown rice flour was added to the wheat flour, the flavonoids content was significantly increased by 180.1% as compared to control flour. Incorporating 24 and 48 h GBR flour to the wheat flour increased flavonoids content by 140.2 and 130.5%, respectively, as compared to wheat flour. Zhang et al. (2010) reported TFC of 0.992 mg rutin equivalent (RE)/g in buck wheat flour. Shen et al. (2009) reported that TFC in rice ranged from 88.6 to 286 mg RE/100 g. However, when the wheat flour was replaced with flour from UBR, a significant increase was noticed in TFC. This increase may be due to synergetic effect of flavonoids present in the rice, as rice is rich source of flavonoids (Shen et al. 2009). Moreover, after replacing the wheat flour with flour from GBR (24 h and 48 h), the TFC was gradually decreased as compared to blend containing UBR flour. The flavonoids are considered phenolic compounds and therefore they may be either metabolized to other compounds or they may leach into the steeping water (Dicko et al., 2005; Urbano et al., 1995). Significant decrease in flavonoids content was observed when all the flour blends and wheat flour (control) were baked into chapatti. The control flour showed a decrease of 28.0% whereas the blends of flour from ungerminated, 24 and 48 h germinated rice showed a decrease of 42.0%, 25.9% and 25.1%, respectively. Zhang et al. (2010) reported a TFC of 0.992 mg RE/g of buck wheat flour which after thermal treatment lowered by 33%. The flavonoids are considered as heat-susceptible phenolic compounds (Zhang et al., 2010; Zhu et al., 2010), hence heat exposure during baking of chapatti could be a reason for decrease in TFC. Figure 1.
Effect of addition of UBR and GBR flour on total flavonoids content of wheat flour blends and chapatti. a, b, c and d superscripts are significantly different (p < 0.05) within the flour blends while p and q show significant difference (p < 0.05) of baking within the blends. UBR is ungerminated brown rice, GBR is germinated brown rice. (▪) Flour Blends, (□) Chapatti.

sec.title: Metal chelating activity
sec.p:
The transition metals have been reported to be catalysts for the initial formation of free radicals. The metal chelators may stabilize metals ions in the living system and inhibit the radical producer hence reduce the free radical damage (Nawar, 1996). Among the wheat flour and flour blends, the highest metal chelating activity was noticed for blend containing flour from 48 h germinated rice followed by UBR, GBR (24 h) and wheat flour (Table 3). However, among the blends, the metal chelating activity was increased significantly by 71.62% after addition of UBR. Further, incorporating the GBR (24 h) lowered the metal chelating activity by 6.5%, but further incorporating GBR (48 h) increased the metal chelating activity by 79.2%. The transition metals have been reported to be catalysts for the initial formation of free radicals. The metal chelators may stabilize metal ions in the living system and inhibit the radical producer hence reducing the damage by free radicals (Nawar, 1996). Yu et al. (2002b) reported a metal-chelating activity of 0.33 mg/g for wheat flour. A significant increase in metal-chelating activity was observed after the wheat flour was replaced with UBR and GBR (24 and 48 h), may be due to the increase in alanine and γ-aminobutyrate and due to synthesis of vitamins C and E (Tian et at., 2004). The metal chelating activity was significantly increased when all the above flour blends and control were baked into chapatti. The metal chelating activity of chapatti prepared from wheat flour was increased to 68.6% while the chapatti prepared from flour blends containing UBR, GBR (24 and 48 h) flour showed the metal chelating activity of 47.8%, 38.9% and 54.4%, respectively. The increase in metal chelating activity may be due to formation of heat-induced compounds such as Maillard reaction products, which may have AOA (Borrelli et al., 2003) Table 3.
Reducing power and metal chelating activity of different blends before and after baking in to chapatti
Reducing power (µmol AAE/g) Metal chelating activity (%)
Blends/Samples Flour Chapatti Flour Chapatti
Control (wheat flour) 23.4 ± 0.1 d, p 33.8 ± 0.1 d, q 4.2 ± 0.6 a, p 68.6 d, q ± 0.3 d, q
UBR 21.5 cp ± 0.2 c, p 27.7 ± 0.2 c, q 14.8 ± 0.4 b, p 47.8 ± 0.6 b, q
GBR (24 h) 20.8 ± 0.1 b, p 24.2 ± 0.3 a, q 13.8 ± 0.2 a, p 38.9 a, q ± 0.7 a, q
GBR (48 h) 19.6 ± 0.4 a, p 25.6 ± 0.1 b, q 24.8 ± 0.8 c, p 54.5 ± 0.7 c, q
Standard error 0.40 1.06 2.11 3.13
Note: Values are mean of three replicates, ± SD. Means followed by a–d are significantly (p < 0.05) different within different blends and by p–q show significant difference of baking within a blend. UBR and GBR are ungerminated brown rice and germinated brown rice, respectively.

sec.title: Reducing power
sec.p: The reducing power is also an indicator of AOA (Lee et al., 2007). The electron donor compounds are considered as a reducing agent and can reduce the oxidized intermediates of the lipid peroxidation reactions; therefore, they may be primary or secondary antioxidants (Zhao et al., 2008). The reducing power of the wheat flour was 23.4 µg AAE/g (Table 3). The addition of rice flour from UBR decreased the reducing power by 8.1%. Further, when the wheat flour was replaced with flour from GBR (24 and 48 h), the reducing power was decreased by 3.3% and 5.8 %, respectively. Compared with the control, the reducing power in GBR was lower (Table 3), while the TPC was higher in GBR (24 h) and was lower in GBR (48 h). The TPC may not be correlated with the reducing power after germination. The phenolic compounds are related to the AOA and reducing power however after germination alteration in the structure of phenolic compounds leads to reduction in their ability to donate electrons, leading to decrease in reducing power (Zhao et al., 2008).

The decrease in reducing power after replacing wheat flour with UBR and GBR flour may be due to dilution of phenolic compounds of wheat flour. In case of blends containing flour from germinated rice, as the duration of germination increased the reducing power decreased; this may be attributed to leaching of phenolic compounds in the soaking water and or due to the degradation of phenolic compounds as a result of enzymatic action (Sharma and Gujral, 2010b; Beta et al., 1999). After baking, the reducing power of chapatti was increased by 44.4% while the increase in reducing power of chapatti containing flour from ungerminated and germinated rice (24 and 48 h) was 28.8%, 16.3% and 30.6%, respectively. The increase in reducing power after baking can be attributed to production of Maillard reaction products that may play a role in antioxidant properties (Woffenden et al., 2002).

GBR flour can be incorporated in whole wheat flour for making chapatti and such chapatti can be used as a delivery vehicle for the bioactive compounds present in GBR. GBR significantly affects the antioxidant properties of the chapatti with the extent of germination duration and baking having significant effects.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The work was funded by the Indian National Science Academy, Young Scientist Grant (INSA Sanction No. SP/YSP/53/2007/4066).
